title: 105_hr846
content: CONSTRUCTIVE SALES TREATMENT FOR APPRECIATED FINANCIAL POSITIONS: Section 1259 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces this treatment for appreciated financial positions. If there is a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position, the taxpayer must recognize gain as if the position were sold for its fair market value on the date of the sale. Any gain is included in the taxable year of the sale, and adjustments are made for subsequent gains or losses. The holding period of the position is determined as if it were acquired on the date of the constructive sale. A taxpayer must recognize gain from a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position as if it were sold at fair market value on the sale date. The gain is included in the taxable year of the sale, with adjustments for subsequent gains or losses. The holding period is determined as if the position were originally acquired on the date of the constructive sale. If the taxpayer (or a related person) engages in certain transactions with the same or substantially identical property, they must recognize gain as if it were sold at fair market value on the sale date. This includes short sales, offsetting notional principal contracts, futures or forward contracts, acquiring the same property, or other transactions with similar effects. The term 'constructive sale' refers to transactions that have the same effect as certain specified transactions, with exceptions for marked-to-market positions, sales of nonpublicly traded property, and transactions closed by year end. The term 'constructive sale' refers to transactions with exceptions for marked-to-market positions and sales of nonpublicly traded property, as well as transactions closed by year end. The term 'constructive sale' refers to transactions with exceptions for marked-to-market positions and sales of nonpublicly traded property. A related person is defined as someone with a transactional relationship aimed at avoiding the purposes of this section. Positions in interest rates are considered substantially identical to debt instruments for tax purposes. Positions in interest rates are treated as substantially identical to debt instruments. Definitions for forward contracts and offsetting notional principal contracts are provided. Special rules apply to the subsequent sale of positions deemed sold. Special rules apply to the subsequent sale of positions deemed sold, where a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position leads to its subsequent sale or disposition, treating the taxpayer as entering into the transaction immediately after the sale. Certain trust instruments are treated as stock. For purposes of this section, an interest in a trust actively traded shall be treated as stock. In the case of a constructive sale of property, the specific property deemed sold is determined as if it were an actual sale. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to carry out the purposes of this section. The Secretary shall prescribe regulations necessary for this section. Securities traders can elect mark to market accounting method for dealers in securities without consent. Securities held for trade or business are not considered for investment. Securities traders can elect mark to market accounting method for dealers in securities without consent. Securities held for trade or business are not considered for investment. The election may be made without the consent of the Secretary and applies to the taxable year for which it is made and all subsequent taxable years unless revoked with the consent of the Secretary. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part IV of subchapter P of chapter 1 of the Code. Sec. 1259 outlines the constructive sales treatment for appreciated financial positions, with specific provisions for the effective date of the amendments. The changes apply to constructive sales occurring after the enactment of the Act, as well as those occurring after January 12, 1996, provided certain conditions are met. The provision applies to constructive sales of appreciated financial positions, with special rules for transactions open before a taxpayer's death. The provision applies to constructive sales of appreciated financial positions, with special rules for transactions open before a taxpayer's death. For purposes of the Internal Revenue Code, such positions shall be treated as property constituting rights to receive income in respect of a decedent. The amendment applies to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. The amendment applies to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act, with a 5-year spread of adjustments for taxpayers changing their accounting method. SEC. 2. LIMITATION ON EXCEPTION FOR INVESTMENT COMPANIES UNDER SECTION 351. The determination of whether a company is an investment company shall consider all stock and securities held by the company, regardless of marketability. Effective for transfers after the enactment date in taxable years ending after such date.
